document.title: Idaho Content Standards American Sign Language

7E40CDCA9F1D4486B5C471F57F499917.description:
show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL for personal
enrichment and career development.

5CDCC845B75C44408DFB411F0283C5B2.description: use technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community;

9A5BD1D422614864A7DDC2FC3ADE8F5A.description:
apply ASL in or out of the school setting through involvement in cultural
activities such as attending Deaf events;

2A7A81CAFFD44194B977402777641C55.description:
apply ASL to demonstrate an understanding of how one language and culture
can influence another.

04D1A07E25974833921E22A3436A4A0F.description:
apply ASL to demonstrate an understanding of the nature of culture through
comparisons of the student's own culture and the American Deaf culture;

CAB2B6700FA74DD09C91B2422CA7632E.description:
apply to demonstrate an understanding of the nature of language through
comparisons of the student's own language and ASL;

D15B077A9CF9410495E66B9A7655C474.description: apply ASL to obtain, reinforce, or expand knowledge of other subject areas.

AB019566FE2E46A6B5ED522B9146AD03.description:
use resources and digital technology to gain access to extensive information
on ASL and Deaf culture;

B31B6B40153F4E40BA5B550286C1573B.description:
demonstrate an in-depth understanding of Deaf history and how it applies to
the perspectives of American Deaf culture.

B4753C5896AC46298F99A33C977722B8.description:
apply ASL to show evidence of appreciation of ASL literature created by the
Deaf and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

DE7DC2712FB7436986C9EB0EF39D98C1.description:
apply ASL to recognize and use Deaf cultural norms to demonstrate an
understanding of the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

A586D134D8304ABF95BE1ED92D602C31.description:
create and express ASL literature, including handshape stories, that follows
traditional cultural features.

1704E1FCA01B4A15BB013C1B8D4FF85D.description:
demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL phonology, morphology, syntax,
semantics, and pragmatics;

3A49B331534B443EA8898F139A4EC07C.description:
convey information in ASL using concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences
to others without voice;

AE5FB77F22ED451F9AC6FA9415775EC4.description:
demonstrate an understanding of ASL such as stories, commands, and
instructions when dealing with familiar and unfamiliar topics;

52D0877C87D7406A9235BA60C2799097.description:
engage in a variety of ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and to
provide and obtain information.

70A0019D097445ACA130D425E67D3827.description:
show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL for personal
enrichment and career development.

7D7E8402435645E18E8C1312378EDBFB.description: use technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community;

perspectives of American Deaf culture.

261F2A9C680D4278B9F8C64009C6D797.description:
show evidence of appreciation of the contributions to arts and sciences by the
Deaf and how they are applied to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

54CC979EB7714B64B36F675C9C3D4279.description:
show evidence of understanding of ASL literature created by the Deaf and
how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

5C22DDFB697E48A582D8CE5D09B484B2.description:

886BF2E0138743BCAB04B76AA13A4083.description: PCL- Plural CL (many people, many cards, many houses, etc)

4D034044BBE04DF884AD55A8A68D6DDE.description: BPCL- Bodypart CL (representing specific parts of the body doing the action)

F968EEA42346476A81E431412B21B27D.description: ICL- Instrument CL (hands usually manipulate an object)

325B3540F22148FAB0CF90C790FCFE47.description: BCL- Body CL (body enacts the verb of a sentence, constructed action dialog is usually required)

A0CA3AE31DA44D1398BD6A2F727B9BBE.description: SCL- Semantic CL (representing a category of nouns such as vehicle or a person)

F1F3A723BB2B4D808D72BCF20979796C.description: LCL- Locative CL (representing an object in a specific place)

8CFCAE81874A4DD88334074DB5A48079.description: DCL- Descriptive CL (describe an object or person)

8373C3E755C142048C0EBC9F2509EC8C.description: create and express the various forms of ASL literature understanding the variant classifiers in primary language:

B7EF3BAA05D84A559D7D00C9762DFCD4.description: demonstrate and use verbs and pronouns in context;

47A80AC278E446868D1A409F93E0D605.description: demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics while discriminating between the parameters of ASL;

2F36397D84DE44F5A1C494D4E79D60C9.description: demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL number signs and fingerspelling in context;

4BBBD0C73F394003B4F2EDB53777C22B.description: understand and convey information in ASL by demonstrating comprehension of single signs, concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences to others without voice;

030B73CFF3624B3F8A112B6BDBCB6FA9.description: demonstrate an understanding of ASL such as stories, everyday commands, exchange of information via questions and answers, and instructions when dealing with familiar topics;

3A465B0E62E14BDAB91DB3622ED0961B.description: engage in various ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and provide and obtain information either structured or spontaneous;

3B27BC00863C43628B19A80A17C69AAD.description: show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL for personal enrichment and/or career development.

BD59FC48DFF249548D6B196D0529B920.description: be aware of methods of technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community;

9BB6016207B5410291ABD1ADC3B9B658.description: apply ASL in or out of the school setting through involvement in cultural activities such as attending Deaf events;

0ED19A8730344462A479F10A46E4F503.description: demonstrate an understanding of how one language and culture can influence another.

55AA82926B3041D589CD500296C1170D.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of culture through comparisons of the student's own culture and the American Deaf culture;

876CE6323D4B4799B95AE7E6F1BC81EE.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of language through comparisons of the student's own language and ASL;

C1AFE2F3EEE347888A838EECEDE171F8.description: use ASL to obtain, reinforce, or expand knowledge of other subject areas.

4C1F6A2542D24261A1760EDC07C8304E.description:
use resources and digital technology to gain access to information about ASL
and Deaf culture;

4D25D13C1297428296A33C156F4EB11D.description: demonstrate an understanding of Deaf history and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture.

3B169F665FCF406082B88E33F1603715.description: show evidence of understanding of the contributions by the Deaf and how they are applied to the perspectives of American Deaf culture such as historical, geographical, political, artistic, and scientific avenues;

F00C6AF572FE4B5EA124711FC7ED70A7.description: show evidence of understanding that ASL literature impacts American Deaf culture;

11061350338B4533B8E2841FD276BA41.description: recognize Deaf cultural norms to demonstrate an understanding of the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

2F01B96D33E74E6AA04BC5DB2E579383.description: PCL- Plural CL (many people, many cards, many houses, etc).

EC9FC781EDD54EA6BC2F0FF9DD67DF99.description: BPCL- Bodypart CL (representing specific parts of the body doing the action)

E15EF96E5A7046D092D228A36BFB355B.description: ICL- Instrument CL (hands usually manipulate an object)

B03403CA9A884824911B2D7294837F8A.description: BCL- Body CL (body enacts the verb of a sentence, constructed action dialog is usually required)

5D4FD5F4F42E459AAFF8BFDA74EABB67.description: SCL- Semantic CL (representing a category of nouns such as vehicle or a person)

53D3803D1E3B4D0EB17750069E4EA30B.description: LCL- Locative CL (representing an object in a specific place)

0E7A1BBFB99A49FC95C20DF844C258C6.description: DCL- Descriptive CL (describe an object or person)

A574DD2A96864D169E410824E204C584.description: demonstrate an understanding of the variant classifiers in primary language:

63D780805FC448958CB47294087AB5DD.description:
demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL and changes in parameters of sign in
phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics;

F304E0644AA64E40B625FC52E1CF684A.description:
demonstrate and use present tense verbs, directional verbs, and personal and
possessive pronouns;

8F3619B1410F401F9F9009C91DC0BD17.description:
demonstrate comprehension and convey information in ASL by number signs,
alphabet, and single fingerspelled words to others without voice;

6841BD0499254D2996F97CDFC6A553CD.description:
demonstrate comprehension and convey information in ASL by single signs,
concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences to others without voice;

67F9EC94D89A475F8BC59A26E82F5AC8.description:
engage in a variety of ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and to
provide and obtain information;
